thread.title: Quebec hospital raises $231K for device but isn't allowed to buy it
thread.title_full: Quebec hospital raises $231K for device but isn't allowed to buy it

author: cbc
title: Quebec hospital raises $231K for device but isn't allowed to buy it
text:
A hospital foundation in Sorel-Tracy, northeast of Montreal, raised close to a quarter of a million dollars to buy an instrument used to diagnose lung cancer, only to have the Quebec Health Ministry reject its plan.
The initiative to buy a bronchoscope was spearheaded by the foundation of the Hôtel-Dieu-de-Sorel.
The foundation raised $231,000 as part of its 2014-2015 fundraising campaign, which was approved by the ministry.
The hospital recruited a pulmonary disease specialist and carried out ventilation renovations to prepare for the installation of the device, which allows doctors to examine a patient's trachea and bronchus without performing surgery.
However, the foundation found out last week the Health Ministry has denied its request to buy the instrument.
"The money is available, the room is available, the pulmonologists are ready, but we have a refusal from the ministry. They can't be serious," said Jocelyn Cayer, the hospital foundation's president.
Quebec aims to crack down on wait times, free up hospital beds with $ 100M plan Device in Saint-Hyacinthe adequate, ministry rules Radio-Canada obtained the letter the regional health authority, the CISSS de la Montérégie Est, sent to the foundation explaining the Health Ministry's refusal.
It said the decision was "essentially based on clinical criteria" and that patients in the Sorel-Tracy area can go to the Saint-Hyacinthe hospital, which has a bronchoscope. That hospital is an hour's drive away.
Before the Liberal caucus meeting in Quebec City Friday, Health Minister Gaétan Barrette said the decision was made at the local level.
While a letter obtained by Radio-Canada said the refusal was a ministerial decision, Health Minister Gaetan Barrette said it was a local decision. (Jacques Boissinot/Canadian Press)
He complained that when he intervenes in local decisions, he's accused of having too much power, but when he doesn't make local decisions, he is also criticized.
In an email, Julie White, Barrette's media attaché, said the purchase of medical equipment is analyzed according to several criteria, including operating costs, how much demand there is for the procedure and whether staff members are trained to use it.
White said the money raised could be used to benefit the local community.
But since the campaign was specifically aimed at buying a bronchoscope, the foundation says it must ask its major partners, such as Rio Tinto and Desjardins, before it can redirect the donations.
Quebec health minister bans user fees Doctors may leave, foundation fears Sorel-Tracy Mayor Serge Péloquin called the decision "unacceptable" and criticized Barrette's health reform plan, which aims to centralize certain services.
Sorel-Tracy Mayor Serge Péloquin says a Health Ministry decision to deny a local hospital's request to buy bronchoscope with money its foundation raised is 'unacceptable.' (Radio-Canada)
He said it's not easy for everyone to get from Sorel to Saint-Hyacinthe, especially in the winter.
Péloquin also pointed out the city has an industrial history and has experienced significant pollution in the past, meaning many citizens have respiratory diseases.
Both Péloquin and the hospital foundation are afraid that doctors may abandon or avoid the hospital because it doesn't have a bronchoscope, which has become a basic diagnostic tool, they say.
